description: From Anglo-Norman tant amount, from amunter, from tant (“as much”) amonter (“to amount to”).

adjectives.description: tantamount (comparative more tantamount, superlative most tantamount)

entries.meaning: Equivalent in meaning or effect; amounting to the same thing in practical terms, even if being technically distinct.
examples: In this view, disagreement and treason are tantamount.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Something which has the same value or amount (as something else). (attributive use passing into adjective, below)
examples: For end thereof, not despondency but madness : for when Cossey understood that Hobday had called his wife a tantamount, he waited for him outside, and gave him what he called a pair of clippers over the ear.

verbs.description: tantamount (third-person singular simple present tantamounts, present participle tantamounting, simple past and past participle tantamounted)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To amount to as much; to be equivalent.
